story.text: As our end user documentation emerges we can expect there to be many questions. We will collect answers here, organize them and then use this to guide improvements.
<b>Is there a better place to ask questions?

Developers ask questions and discuss features by posting issues to various github repositories. Smallest-Federated-Wiki remains the most watched repo even though actual work has moved to the many repos within the FedWiki organization. [https://github.com/issues?q=user%3Afedwiki+is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+repo%3AWardCunningham%2FSmallest-Federated-Wiki issues].

We meet in a video chat every Wednesday at 10am west coast (pacific) time. We try several free services. Explore. [https://hangouts.google.com/call/vh8qSgMVs-k-qOFdtwDAAAEI hangout] or [https://zoom.us/j/818108478 zoom]

Video Chat Every Wednesday
IN US/Pacific
DATE Wednesday
TIME 10:00
HERE
Our alternative video chat is the html5 webrtc system appear.in. [https://appear.in/fedwiki chat]
Matrix is a whole ecosystem of matrix-enabled clients, servers, gateways, application services, bots, etc. We're in the matrix. [https://matrix.to/#/#fedwiki:matrix.org #fedwiki:matrix.org]
We have a forum running at [https://socio.federated.wiki/ socio]. This is a quiet place but good for complex questions discussed with experts.
There is an IRC channel, #fedwiki on irc.freenode.net. Connect with your favorite IRC client or use the freenode web interface. [http://webchat.freenode.net/?channels=fedwiki freenode]

<b>Is there some documentation for those iconic buttons at the bottom of an article? I see that they are adding up and creating a history, I just don't get what they are doing, what they are for, or what they mean.

The unicode icons depict the performed action. The current list of actions are: move, edit, add, remove, and fork. Older versions showed a first character of the action. Hover to see the complete name.
<b>In terms of the full vision of the project, when you fork or pull in content from another server in the federation, will you pull in its history also?
Yes. A federated wiki page is its Story and its Journal.
See [[Names of Things]] for basic terminology.
Do you always make a point of using the full name Smallest Federated Wiki, perhaps to encourage development of something like brand awareness?

I use the term Smallest Federated Wiki when referring to the original project and its repository. [https://github.com/WardCunningham/Smallest-Federated-Wiki github]

I use the term Federated Wiki when referring to the communities that will grow from this and compatible work including our new preferred source code. [https://github.com/fedwiki github]
<b>How do I tell where a page is located? How do I create page that lives somewhere besides the server being visited?

When you click on the flag (favicon) of any federated wiki page you go to the Welcome Visitors for that page's site. By convention this page links to pages for the site's owner and more content that the owner curates on your behalf. See [[More About Browsing and Linking Sites]].

item.text: Click the [+] at the bottom of this page to add a question. Double-click the box that appears. Type your question. Press [[Control-S]] to save.
<b>Is there a better place to ask questions?
We hold meetups occasionally in Portland. Watch Calagator for announcements.

<b>Is there some documentation for those letter buttons at the bottom of an article? I see that they are adding up and creating a history, I just don't get what they are doing, what they are for, or what they mean.
<b>In terms of the full vision of the project, when you fork or pull in content from another server in the federation, will you pull in its history also?
There is a Google Group mailing list. It hasn't caught on.
The letters were ment to be icons. For now we extract the first letter of action type: m for move, e for edit, etc.
Yes. A wiki page is its Story and its Journal.
See [https://github.com/WardCunningham/Smallest-Federated-Wiki/wiki/Concepts Concepts].
See [https://github.com/WardCunningham/Smallest-Federated-Wiki/wiki/Concepts Concepts] for basic terminology.
If the Journal gets long, there are many ways to shorten it. For example, keep only the Forks and Actions since the last Fork

Click the [+] at the bottom of this page TWICE to make room for a new question and its answer. Double-click the first box that appears. Type your question. Press [[Control-S]] to save. Come back to see when the answer box gets filled.
Click the [+] at the bottom of this page TWICE to make room for a new question and its answer. Double-click the first box that appears. Come back to see when the answer box gets filled.

Click the [+] at the bottom of this page TWICE to make room for a new question and its answer. Double-click the first box that appears. Enter your question. Come back to see when the answer box gets filled.
We hold meetups occasionally in Portland. Watch [http://calagator.org/ Calagator] for announcements.
Developers ask questions and discuss features by posting issues to the GitHub project.
Developers ask questions and discuss features by posting issues to the [https://github.com/WardCunningham/Smallest-Federated-Wiki GitHub project].
A public Google+ video hangout meets Wednesday mornings at 10 am pacific time (UTC +8 in the winter).
The letters are drawn from the first character of the action perform. The current list of actions are: move, edit, add, remove, and fork.
Yes. A federated wiki page is its Story and its Journal.
As our end user documentation emerges we can expect there to be many questions. We will collect answers here, organize them and then eventually improve our documentation.
As our end user documentation emerges we can expect there to be many questions. We will collect answers here, organize them and then use this to guide improvements.
<b>Where is this site hosted?
Do you always make a point of using the full name Smallest Federated Wiki, perhaps to encourage development of something like brand awareness?

I use the term Smallest Federated Wiki when referring to this project. I use the term Federated Wiki when referring to the communities that I believe will emerge based on work explored first here. SFW is a reasonable shorthand when referring to this project among those familiar with it. This project has, since day one, been done in public on GitHub. You might enjoy reading some of the first commits.

I use the term Smallest Federated Wiki when referring to the [https://github.com/wardcunningham/SmallestFederatedWiki GitHub project]. I use the term Federated Wiki when referring to the communities that I believe will emerge based on work explored first here. SFW is a reasonable shorthand when referring to this project among those familiar with it. This project has, since day one, been done in public on GitHub. You might enjoy reading some of the first commits.

SFW is a reasonable shorthand when referring to that project among those familiar with it. The project has, since day one, been done in public. You might enjoy reading some of the first commits.

SFW is a reasonable shorthand when referring to that project among those familiar with it.

SFW is a reasonable shorthand when referring to that project among those familiar with it.
A public Google+ [https://plus.google.com/hangouts/extras/talk.google.com/fedwiki video hangout] meets Wednesday mornings at 10 am pacific time (UTC +8 in the winter).
There is an IRC channel, #fedwiki on freenode.net.
<b>How do I tell where a page is located? How do I create page that lives somewhere besides the server being visited?

When you click on the flag (favicon) of any federated wiki page you go to the Welcome Visitors for that page's site. By convention this page links to pages for the site's owner and more content that the owner curates on your behalf. See [[More About Browsing and Linking Sites]].

The letters are drawn from the first character of the action perform. The current list of actions are: move, edit, add, remove, and fork. Newer versions replace letters with unicode symbols that suggest the action.
